text: Lecture 1: Introduction to International Trade II. WHY STUDY INTERNATIONAL TRADE? • Governments restrict movement of goods/services & factors of production • Restrictions strongest on labor (immigration) and capital (FDI) • Technology doesn’t flow easily across borders: - Tied to human capital & institutions (legal systems, infrastructure) • Example: U.S. Constitution enables free intra-state commerce, unlike international trade • Trade is politically divisive: - Bipartisan disagreement (e.g., Trump & Biden both criticized NAFTA) - Skepticism among general public (Gallup poll on NAFTA) - Economists overwhelmingly support trade (IGM Chicago panel) III. WHAT IS GLOBALIZATION? Definition (Deardorff & Stern): 1. Increase in international market transactions (goods, services, factors) 2. Expansion of multinational corporations and global institutions (UN, IMF, WTO) • Globalization Metrics: - Trade flows (goods & services) - Foreign asset ownership - Immigration - Price convergence • Historical Trends: - 2 waves: late 1800s and post-WW2 - U.S. and Japan: relatively closed compared to other advanced economies IV. CONSEQUENCES OF GLOBALIZATION • Job market changes: - Manufacturing decline (see FRED data) - Shift to services - Rise in skill premium - Shrinking middle class (Pew data) - Routine jobs replaced by nonroutine jobs (Census Bureau) • Other Concerns: - Cultural

relatively closed compared to other advanced economies IV. CONSEQUENCES OF GLOBALIZATION • Job market changes: - Manufacturing decline (see FRED data) - Shift to services - Rise in skill premium - Shrinking middle class (Pew data) - Routine jobs replaced by nonroutine jobs (Census Bureau) • Other Concerns: - Cultural loss - Environmental impact - Loss of government control (multinationals, internet) V. DRIVERS OF GLOBAL TRADE GROWTH 1. **Shipping Costs Decline**: - Container shipping (1956) - Air freight (IATA stats) - Short-run pandemic spikes 2. **Communication Advances**: - Lower phone/satellite/internet costs 3. **Trade Policy Liberalization**: - Tariff reductions across G20, developing nations 4. **Capital & Labor Mobility**: - FDI growth (UNCTAD) - Immigration trends (Census data) 5. **Price Convergence**: - Example: Grain price gaps (Chicago vs. Liverpool) • But note: U.S.–China tariffs have risen recently (Trade War data) End of Lecture 1 Notes

Lecture 10: Production Functions INTRODUCTION TO MULTIPLE FACTORS • Adds capital (K) alongside labor (L) in production. • Some factors (e.g. labor) are more flexible than others across sectors or regions. • U.S. labor adjusts within ~6 years post-shock; capital adjusts over decades. PRODUCTION FUNCTION PROPERTIES • Production with two factors: QC = FC(KC, LC), QF = FF(KF, LF) • Constant returns to scale: F(tK, tL) = tF(K, L) • Diminishing marginal returns: MPK and MPL decline in own input. • Factor complementarity: MPK rises with L, MPL rises with K. MARGINAL PRODUCTS • MPK = ∂F/∂K, MPL = ∂F/∂L ≥ 0 • With constant returns to scale, proportional input changes keep MP constant. FACTOR PRICING AND COST • Competitive markets: w = p × MPL, r = p × MPK • Prices equal marginal cost: p = MC = AC = (rK + wL)/Q • No profits under constant returns to scale: π = 0 ISOQUANTS • Isoquants: input combinations yielding same output. • Unit isoquant shows (K, L) for one unit of output. • Slope = −MPL/MPK • More curved isoquants = less substitutability. COST MINIMIZATION • Firms choose (K, L) to minimize rK + wL for fixed

returns to scale: π = 0 ISOQUANTS • Isoquants: input combinations yielding same output. • Unit isoquant shows (K, L) for one unit of output. • Slope = −MPL/MPK • More curved isoquants = less substitutability. COST MINIMIZATION • Firms choose (K, L) to minimize rK + wL for fixed Q. • Optimal condition: MPL/MPK = w/r • Implies unit cost = waLC + raKC • Constant input ratios under constant returns: LC/KC fixed RELATIVE FACTOR DEMAND • Relative demand for L/K is downward sloping in w/r. • Analogous to relative demand for goods. LEONTIEF TECHNOLOGY • No substitutability: Q = min(LC/aLC, KC/aKC) • Fixed proportions of inputs. • Graph on page 20 shows right-angled isoquants. FACTOR INTENSITY • C is labor-intensive if aLC/aKC > aLF/aKF. • Labor share in cost: wLC/(wLC + rKC) > wLF/(wLF + rKF) FACTOR INTENSITY REVERSALS • When RD curves cross, factor intensity depends on w/r. • Called a factor intensity reversal. • This is treated as a special case and usually ignored. End of Lecture 10 Notes
w/r. • Called a factor intensity reversal. • This is treated as a special case and usually ignored. End of Lecture 10 Notes

Lecture 2: The Basics of International Trade I. WHAT DOES THE WORLD ECONOMY LOOK LIKE? • World trade is dominated by: - Manufactured goods (~60%) - Services (~20%) - Mining (incl. fuels) and agriculture in some regions (see page 3-4) • Country Export Snapshots (2020): - **U.S.**: ICT, insurance/finance, soybeans, cars, petroleum - **France**: ICT, transport, wine, pharmaceuticals - **China**: ICT, electronics, toys, lamps - **Saudi Arabia**: Crude oil (53%+), refined oil, polymers - **Mali** (2013): Gold (74%), cotton, raw materials • Top U.S. Import Categories (2015): - Electrical machinery, oil, vehicles, computers, medical equipment • Top U.S. Export Categories (2016): - Machinery, aircraft, vehicles, plastics — mainly intra-industry trade • Top Traders: - Leading exporters (2015): China, U.S., Germany - Leading service traders: U.S., China, Germany (see page 17-18) • Trade Openness: - Hong Kong, Singapore: trade/GDP > 100% - U.S., Japan: much lower openness (~25-30%) II. WHO TRADES WITH WHOM? • Trade is influenced by: - Geography (distance) - Country size (GDP) - Cultural/language ties - Common borders, trade agreements, colonial history • **Gravity Equation** for Trade: Tij = A * (Yi)^a * (Yj)^b / (Dij)^c - Trade ∝ country size - Trade ∝ 1/distance - Coefficients a,

WITH WHOM? • Trade is influenced by: - Geography (distance) - Country size (GDP) - Cultural/language ties - Common borders, trade agreements, colonial history • **Gravity Equation** for Trade: Tij = A * (Yi)^a * (Yj)^b / (Dij)^c - Trade ∝ country size - Trade ∝ 1/distance - Coefficients a, b, c ≈ 1 in empirical studies • Even with tech and shipping improvements, distance still matters (pg. 24) • U.S. trades more with closer nations (e.g., Canada, Mexico) despite EU size III. GAINS FROM TRADE • Trade is **mutually beneficial**: - Consumers get cheaper/better imports - Exporting firms access new markets • But there are **losers**: - Domestic firms facing foreign competition - Workers in declining sectors - Even these groups benefit as consumers • Question: If internal trade is good, why should international trade be feared? • Differences across countries: - Technology, labor, capital, raw materials - Government institutions and human capital IV. A SURPRISING ANALOGY: "Growing Cars in Iowa" • An economist’s parable: - Instead of building cars in Detroit, grow wheat in Iowa, export it, and import Hondas — the **same result**. - Trade ≈ **indirect production via exchange** V. TRADE ≈ TECHNOLOGICAL CHANGE Scenario 1:

institutions and human capital IV. A SURPRISING ANALOGY: "Growing Cars in Iowa" • An economist’s parable: - Instead of building cars in Detroit, grow wheat in Iowa, export it, and import Hondas — the **same result**. - Trade ≈ **indirect production via exchange** V. TRADE ≈ TECHNOLOGICAL CHANGE Scenario 1: Trade • Use existing tech to make exports and receive imports. Scenario 2: New Tech • Tech transforms same inputs into a new good directly. Conclusion: • Both create winners/losers across sectors. • Both cause long-run shifts in labor markets and job types. VI. CONCERNS ABOUT TRADE • Labor Standards: - Workers' rights, working conditions, child labor • Market Failures: - Infant industries, monopolies, externalities (e.g., pollution) - Public/cultural goods - Trade restrictions might help, but are often misused VII. ECONOMIC MODELS IN TRADE • Models simplify reality — don’t ask if they're **true**, ask: - What assumptions matter most? - Would results change under different assumptions? • Key modeling assumptions: - Factors mobile **within** but not **across** countries - Technology and factor endowments vary by country - Consumer tastes often assumed similar End of Lecture 2 Notes

- Would results change under different assumptions? • Key modeling assumptions: - Factors mobile **within** but not **across** countries - Technology and factor endowments vary by country - Consumer tastes often assumed similar End of Lecture 2 Notes

Lecture 3: Preferences and Demand Course: 14.54 (Fall 2024) — Week 2 I. UTILITY MAXIMIZATION • Two goods: Cloth (C) and Food (F) • Consumption bundle: D = (DC, DF) • Budget set defined by: pC * DC + pF * DF ≤ I • With endowment E = (EC, EF), budget constraint becomes: pC * DC + pF * DF = pC * EC + pF * EF ⇒ Only relative price pC/pF matters II. PREFERENCES • Represented by utility function: U(DC, DF) • Utility is ordinal — only rankings matter • Common transforms: U + a, aU, U², √U, logU, e^U — same preferences • Marginal Utility: - MUC = ∂U/∂DC ≥ 0 - MUF = ∂U/∂DF ≥ 0 • Preferences summarized by indifference curves: U(DC, DF) = constant III. MARGINAL RATE OF SUBSTITUTION (MRS) • MRS = MUC / MUF — the slope of the indifference curve • Interpreted as how much F a consumer gives up for 1 unit of C • Use absolute value: MRS > 0 • MRS = −MUC/MUF is sometimes used • Convex Preferences: - Indifference curves bowed to origin - MRS decreases as C increases - C becomes less valuable as

• Interpreted as how much F a consumer gives up for 1 unit of C • Use absolute value: MRS > 0 • MRS = −MUC/MUF is sometimes used • Convex Preferences: - Indifference curves bowed to origin - MRS decreases as C increases - C becomes less valuable as more is consumed IV. PREFERENCE EXAMPLES 1. **Linear Preferences**: U(DC, DF) = aDC + bDF → MRS is constant at a/b (perfect substitutes) 2. **Leontief Preferences**: U(DC, DF) = min{aDC, bDF} → No substitutability (perfect complements) V. UTILITY MAXIMIZATION CONDITIONS • Optimal choice when: MRS = pC/pF (tangency condition) • If MRS > pC/pF → consumer trades F for C • If MRS < pC/pF → consumer trades C for F • Corner solutions: - DC = 0 if MRS < pC/pF at that point - DF = 0 if MRS > pC/pF at that point VI. RELATIVE DEMAND • Optimal demand depends on pC/pF and endowment E • Relative demand curve: DC/DF as a function of pC/pF • RD curves reflect how preferences and endowments shape demand VII. HOMOTHETIC PREFERENCES • Definition: MRS is constant along rays from origin • Examples: - Cobb-Douglas: U(DC, DF) = DC^a * DF^b

Optimal demand depends on pC/pF and endowment E • Relative demand curve: DC/DF as a function of pC/pF • RD curves reflect how preferences and endowments shape demand VII. HOMOTHETIC PREFERENCES • Definition: MRS is constant along rays from origin • Examples: - Cobb-Douglas: U(DC, DF) = DC^a * DF^b • Spending shares: a/(a + b), b/(a + b) - Linear and Leontief preferences • Key Property: - If preferences are homothetic → same consumption ratios across incomes - Demand scales proportionally with income - RD curve is independent of endowment VIII. AGGREGATION • If all consumers have same homothetic preferences: - Aggregate demand can be modeled as if from a single consumer - Demand depends only on aggregate endowment, not its distribution • Welfare Implication: - Aggregate utility may rise even if some individuals are worse off End of Lecture 3 Notes

Lecture 4: Exchange Economies –––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––– ENDOWMENT ECONOMY FRAMEWORK • Two goods: Cloth (C), Food (F) • Country has fixed endowment: E = (EC, EF) • All consumers share homothetic preferences ⇒ aggregate demand behaves like a single representative consumer –––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––– KEY CONCEPTS • Relative Price: pC / pF (terms of trade) • In autarky: MRS = pC / pF at the endowment point • In open economy: consumers can trade along the budget line defined by world price pT –––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––– AUTARKY VS. OPEN ECONOMY Autarky: - Consumption = Endowment - Relative price = MRS at endowment - No trade, utility UA Open Economy: - Consumers trade at world price pT - If pT > MRS → export F, import C - If pT < MRS → export C, import F - Trade expands consumption beyond endowment –––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––– GAINS FROM TRADE • Gains exist when consumption moves to a higher indifference curve • Always possible when pT ≠ MRS • Trade direction determined by pT relative to autarky MRS –––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––– TWO-COUNTRY EQUILIBRIUM • Trade price must satisfy: MRSE < pT < MRSE* - Home exports good it has in relative abundance - Foreign does the opposite • No trade if both

curve • Always possible when pT ≠ MRS • Trade direction determined by pT relative to autarky MRS –––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––– TWO-COUNTRY EQUILIBRIUM • Trade price must satisfy: MRSE < pT < MRSE* - Home exports good it has in relative abundance - Foreign does the opposite • No trade if both countries want to export the same good –––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––– COMPARATIVE ADVANTAGE • A country has a comparative advantage in good X if its autarky price is lower than world price • If EC/EF > E*C/E*F → Home exports C • Comparative advantage based on relative, not absolute, endowments –––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––– EQUILIBRIUM TRADE PRICE • World relative demand (RD) = aggregated demand from both countries • World relative supply (RS) = (EC + E*C) / (EF + E*F) • Equilibrium pT solves: RD(pT) = RS –––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––– DIFFERENT PREFERENCES • If countries have different homothetic preferences: - RD depends on both preferences and endowments - Still get equilibrium from RD ∩ RS –––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––– End of Trimmed Lecture 4 Notes

Lecture 5: Exchange Economies II — Welfare, Inequality, and Trade Imbalances EDGEWORTH BOX AND TRADE GAINS • Edgeworth box illustrates trade possibilities when countries differ in marginal rates of substitution (MRS). • Example 1: MRS^E < MRS^E* — gains from trade where Home exports C. • Example 2: MRS^E > MRS^E* — gains from trade where Home exports F. EQUILIBRIUM TRADE PRICE • Arbitrary trade price p^T is not an equilibrium if one side wants to export more than the other wants to import. • Equilibrium: indifference curves must be tangent — all gains from trade are exhausted. • Pareto efficiency: no one can be made better off without making someone else worse off. • The contract curve in the Edgeworth box contains all Pareto efficient allocations. IMPACT OF TRADE BARRIERS • Tariffs or distortions break the equal-MRS condition across countries. • Result: Inefficiency and missed gains from trade. REDISTRIBUTIVE EFFECTS OF TRADE • Question: Do aggregate gains imply gains for everyone? • Setup: Consumers share homothetic preferences but differ in endowments. • Example: GM vs. Pharma workers — gains depend on factor ownership. • Trade can benefit some more than others, and intra-national trade may offer better gains than

EFFECTS OF TRADE • Question: Do aggregate gains imply gains for everyone? • Setup: Consumers share homothetic preferences but differ in endowments. • Example: GM vs. Pharma workers — gains depend on factor ownership. • Trade can benefit some more than others, and intra-national trade may offer better gains than international trade for some individuals. • Not all individuals gain equally: - Some gain more from within-country trade. - Consumer 1 gains less than average; Consumer 2 gains more. • Redistributive policies: - Government can reallocate endowments (e.g., taxes, transfers). - Full redistribution can make everyone better off from trade. - Hard to implement practically. DEVELOPED COUNTRY ANALOGY • High-tech (H) vs. low-tech (L) workers. • Developed countries are H-abundant. • Trade increases p_H / p_L → helps H workers, hurts L workers. • Trade restrictions can reduce inequality but lower overall income. • Better alternative: redistribute through transfers or taxes. • Over time, L workers may become H workers. TRADE OVER TIME AND BALANCE OF TRADE • Static models assume balanced trade; real world allows trade over time. • Model: Two periods with aggregate consumption in each. • Consumers care about present vs. future consumption. • Without inter-temporal trade

taxes. • Over time, L workers may become H workers. TRADE OVER TIME AND BALANCE OF TRADE • Static models assume balanced trade; real world allows trade over time. • Model: Two periods with aggregate consumption in each. • Consumers care about present vs. future consumption. • Without inter-temporal trade → consume at endowment. • With borrowing/lending → smooth consumption across time. • If country expects to be richer tomorrow: - Borrows today (consumes more now), repays later. - Intertemporal trade optimal point is beyond endowment. EXPLAINING U.S. TRADE DEFICITS • Explanation 1: U.S. expects higher productivity tomorrow than rest of world. • Explanation 2: U.S. consumers are more impatient. End of Lecture 5 Notes

Lecture 6: Standard Trade Models Production Possibility Frontier • PPF = set of goods that can be produced given technology and factor endowments. • In the long run, production responds to changes in relative prices (like consumer demand). • Movement along the PPF represents reallocation of factors between sectors (C and F). • PPF is downward sloping; slope = MRT (Marginal Rate of Transformation) = opportunity cost. • MRT also equals relative marginal cost of producing C. • PPF is typically bowed outward: relative MC increases as more of a good is produced. Why are marginal costs increasing? • Due to differences in factors — some are better suited to producing specific goods. • Example: Farmer with 3 fields yields higher productivity when allocating efficiently across crops. • Even with homogeneous factors, different input proportions can yield increasing MC. Revenue Maximization • Firms maximize revenue subject to PPF: choose (QC, QF) to maximize pC * QC + pF * QF. • At equilibrium, slope of PPF = relative price. Aggregation • Individual (or country) PPFs can be combined into a world PPF. • Points on the world PPF represent efficient combinations only when RMC^1 = RMC^2. • All producers facing

QF) to maximize pC * QC + pF * QF. • At equilibrium, slope of PPF = relative price. Aggregation • Individual (or country) PPFs can be combined into a world PPF. • Points on the world PPF represent efficient combinations only when RMC^1 = RMC^2. • All producers facing same price pC/pF will maximize revenue at points along the aggregate PPF. PPF and Relative Supply • Relative supply RS(pC/pF) = QC / QF derived from optimizing production under a given price. • RS does not reflect country size — only shape of PPF matters. • Growth can shift PPF, changing RS — especially if growth is biased toward one good. Different Countries and RS • Differences in RS curves arise from differences in technology and factor abundance. Elasticity of RS Over Time • RS becomes more elastic in the long run due to increased production flexibility. Country Revenue Maximization and World PPF • Countries face the same world relative price p^T = pC^T / pF^T • World relative supply curve lies between the two country RS curves. • World supply is a weighted average of individual country RS. Autarky Equilibrium • Consumers share homothetic preferences. • Equilibrium p^A satisfies

and World PPF • Countries face the same world relative price p^T = pC^T / pF^T • World relative supply curve lies between the two country RS curves. • World supply is a weighted average of individual country RS. Autarky Equilibrium • Consumers share homothetic preferences. • Equilibrium p^A satisfies RS(p^A) = RD(p^A), where p^A = MRS^A = MRT^A. • At p^A, value of production and consumer utility are both maximized. Trade Equilibrium • At world price p^T > p^A, production moves to Q, and country exports C, imports F. • Gains from trade raise welfare from U^A to U^T. • Equilibrium p^T: export supply = import demand globally. Short-Run vs Long-Run Trade Responses • In short run, production may not respond. • In long run, reallocation increases trade volume and gains. • Transition costs (e.g., unemployment) occur during reallocation. • These costs should be weighed against long-term welfare gains. End of Lecture 6 Notes
End of Lecture 6 Notes

Lecture 7: Standard Trade Model (II) — Changes in Terms of Trade SHORT-RUN IMPACTS IN A SMALL OPEN ECONOMY • A country trades at world price p^T. Changes in p^T affect it via the terms of trade. • If the country exports C, an increase in p^T improves its terms of trade (TOT). • In the short run (fixed production Q), an increase in p^T shifts the budget constraint outward. • Diagram (p.6): Shows equilibrium movement from Q^A to Q^T and higher utility level. INCOME AND SUBSTITUTION EFFECTS Case 1: p^T increases (TOT improves) • Substitution effect: consume less of the export good (C), more of the import good (F). • Income effect: overall higher purchasing power. • DF increases (both effects reinforce), DC change is ambiguous (opposing effects). Case 2: p^T decreases (TOT worsens) • Substitution effect: consume more C, less F. • Income effect: loss in real income. • DF decreases (reinforced), DC change ambiguous. Case 3: Exporter of F experiences price drop • Substitution effect unchanged, income effect reversed. • DC must increase, DF change ambiguous. LONG-RUN EFFECTS • With production response, effects are magnified: - Increase in p^T → more production of C, greater consumption of

• DF decreases (reinforced), DC change ambiguous. Case 3: Exporter of F experiences price drop • Substitution effect unchanged, income effect reversed. • DC must increase, DF change ambiguous. LONG-RUN EFFECTS • With production response, effects are magnified: - Increase in p^T → more production of C, greater consumption of F. - Diagram (p.13): PPF shifts with consumption gains. • Welfare effect from production never overturns the income effect unless trade direction reverses. TRADE FLOWS • Demand: DF ↑ and DC ↓ or ↑ • Production: QC ↑, QF ↓ (along PPF) • Imports = DF − QF ↑; Exports = QC − DC ambiguous but usually increase. • Summary: - Import demand curves are downward sloping. - Export supply curves usually upward sloping, but may bend backward if income effects dominate. TERMS OF TRADE AND WELFARE • TOT declines reduce welfare until autarky. • Large long-run TOT declines can reverse trade patterns (empirically rare). • Quantitative estimate: - ∆Welfare = Trade Share of GDP × %∆p^T - Developed: 20% × 1% = 0.2% GDP - Developing: up to 12.5% of GDP from TOT shocks CHANGES IN WORLD RELATIVE PRICES • Only large countries affect p^T. • p^T depends on

reverse trade patterns (empirically rare). • Quantitative estimate: - ∆Welfare = Trade Share of GDP × %∆p^T - Developed: 20% × 1% = 0.2% GDP - Developing: up to 12.5% of GDP from TOT shocks CHANGES IN WORLD RELATIVE PRICES • Only large countries affect p^T. • p^T depends on shifts in world RD^W and RS^W. • Changes in RD^W due to income or taste shifts (minor effects). • RS^W changes more impactful: - E.g. OPEC’s supply reduction raises oil prices (p.28) - Entry of large exporters (e.g., China) shifts RS outward, lowers p^T of manufactured goods. GROWTH AND TERMS OF TRADE • Unbiased growth increases output without shifting RS — improves foreign’s TOT, hurts home’s. • Biased growth: - Toward exports → worsens TOT. - Toward imports → can offset TOT effects. • Extreme case: Immiserizing growth — when TOT decline outweighs output gains. - Diagram (p.34): Shows shift inward despite growth. - More likely if demand for exports is inelastic and growth is export-biased. TRADE POLICY AND TERMS OF TRADE Import Tariffs and Export Subsidies: • In small countries: change internal prices, not p^T. • Welfare losses due to distorted domestic prices (p.39). • In large countries: change

inward despite growth. - More likely if demand for exports is inelastic and growth is export-biased. TRADE POLICY AND TERMS OF TRADE Import Tariffs and Export Subsidies: • In small countries: change internal prices, not p^T. • Welfare losses due to distorted domestic prices (p.39). • In large countries: change both domestic and world prices. - Small tariff can improve TOT and welfare. - Large tariff reverses effect. • Export subsidies: always reduce TOT, especially in large countries (p.43). • Optimal tariff exists for large countries, but leads to global welfare loss if universally applied. End of Lecture 7 Notes

Lecture 8: Ricardian Trade Model INTRODUCTION • Introduces technology and factor endowments as determinants of comparative advantage. • Trade patterns emerge from technology differences, assuming similar preferences. • Focus: technology determines production possibilities, wages, and welfare outcomes. RICARDIAN MODEL BASICS • One factor: labor; constant returns to scale. • Unit labor requirement: # of labor units needed per unit of output. • Labor moves freely across sectors → wages equalize across sectors. • Competitive labor and output markets; wages = marginal product value. COUNTRY PPF • Let aLC, aLF = labor requirements for cloth and food. • PPF: aLC * QC + aLF * QF = L • Productivity = 1/aLC or 1/aLF • Increases in productivity or L shift the PPF outward. AUTARKY AND TRADE EQUILIBRIUM • Autarky price: pA = aLC / aLF • Trade equilibrium depends on world price pT: - If pT > aLC/aLF → specialize in C - If pT < aLC/aLF → specialize in F - If pT = aLC/aLF → produce anywhere on PPF COMPARATIVE ADVANTAGE • Home has comparative advantage in C if aLC/aLF < a*LC/a*LF • Relative productivity matters, not absolute. • Country size L and L* don’t affect the trade

in C - If pT < aLC/aLF → specialize in F - If pT = aLC/aLF → produce anywhere on PPF COMPARATIVE ADVANTAGE • Home has comparative advantage in C if aLC/aLF < a*LC/a*LF • Relative productivity matters, not absolute. • Country size L and L* don’t affect the trade pattern. WORLD SUPPLY AND SPECIALIZATION • If pT < aLC/aLF → both specialize in F • If pT > a*LC/a*LF → both specialize in C • If aLC/aLF < pT < a*LC/a*LF → specialization by comparative advantage EQUILIBRIUM TRADE PRICE • Equilibrium pT must fall between the countries' autarky prices. • Complete specialization is typical, but large countries may not fully specialize. WORLD PPF EXAMPLE • Home: L=1200, aLC=6, aLF=6 • Foreign: L=400, a*LC=4, a*LF=1 • Diagram (page 17–18): shows kinks and joint world PPF EQUILIBRIUM ON WORLD PPF • Diagram (page 19): trade equilibrium occurs where world indifference curve is tangent to world PPF. PRODUCTIVITY AND WAGES • Sector wage: w = pC/aLC (cloth), w = pF/aLF (food) • Wage equalization implies pC/pF = aLC/aLF in diversified production. • In specialization: wage = pi / aLi WAGES UNDER SPECIALIZATION • When specializing in C: F production stops if wF

is tangent to world PPF. PRODUCTIVITY AND WAGES • Sector wage: w = pC/aLC (cloth), w = pF/aLF (food) • Wage equalization implies pC/pF = aLC/aLF in diversified production. • In specialization: wage = pi / aLi WAGES UNDER SPECIALIZATION • When specializing in C: F production stops if wF < wC. • Importing is cheaper than producing domestically when wage × aLF > pF. INTERNATIONAL WAGES • With specialization: - Home wage: w = pC / aLC - Foreign wage: w* = pF / a*LF - Relative wage: w/w* = pT × (a*LF / aLC) • Relative wage depends on terms of trade and productivity. PRODUCTIVITY AND WELFARE • Comparative advantage (relative productivity) → trade pattern • Absolute productivity → welfare level • Gains from trade do not depend on absolute productivity • Increases in productivity yield direct (domestic) and indirect (via TOT) welfare gains End of Lecture 8 Notes
Notes

Lecture 9: Extensions of the Ricardian Model I. EMPIRICAL EVIDENCE ON RICARDIAN MECHANISMS • Cross-country wage differences are roughly proportional to productivity levels (see wage-productivity chart, p.4). • Over time, countries with rising productivity (e.g., Japan, Korea) also experience rising wages (p.5). • Despite wage gaps, developed countries can still compete due to relative productivity advantages. II. TRADE BETWEEN UNEQUAL COUNTRIES • Key question: Can high-wage countries compete with low-wage countries? • Historical concerns: Ross Perot (1990s) and Donald Trump (2016) warned about job losses due to cheap foreign labor. • Counterpoint: Not all jobs relocate—relative productivity differences explain trade, not absolute wages. • Even if a country pays lower wages, if it is less productive, it may not gain trade advantage. • Ricardian insight: comparative, not absolute, advantage determines trade. III. CHINA AND LOW-WAGE COMPETITION • Graph (p.11) shows China’s rising hourly manufacturing wages (2002–2009). • Despite low wages, China’s productivity gains made it competitive. IV. SATIRE ON TRADE PROTECTIONISM • Bastiat's "Petition of the Candle Makers" (1845) critiques protectionist logic. • Argues against blocking sunlight to protect the domestic lighting industry—a metaphor for free trade benefits. V. EVIDENCE ON EXPORT PATTERNS AND PRODUCTIVITY • U.S. exports are higher

China’s productivity gains made it competitive. IV. SATIRE ON TRADE PROTECTIONISM • Bastiat's "Petition of the Candle Makers" (1845) critiques protectionist logic. • Argues against blocking sunlight to protect the domestic lighting industry—a metaphor for free trade benefits. V. EVIDENCE ON EXPORT PATTERNS AND PRODUCTIVITY • U.S. exports are higher in industries with greater relative productivity compared to the U.K. (p.15–16). • Agricultural study (Costinot & Donaldson 2012) shows relative productivity differences explain crop choices (p.17–18). VI. LIMITATIONS OF RICARDIAN MODEL • Cannot explain: - Long-run distributional effects - Intra-industry trade - Trade due to returns to scale or factor abundance VII. EXTENSION 1: NON-TRADED GOODS • Goods produced domestically and not traded (e.g., services). • Wage determined by most profitable export: w = pTi / aLi • Non-traded goods' prices adjust: pk = waLk = pTi × (aLk / aLi) • Productivity growth in traded goods raises wages, raising pk over time. • Explains rising service prices despite no productivity gain — the Balassa-Samuelson effect (p.48–49). VIII. EXTENSION 2: MULTIPLE TRADED GOODS • Two-country model with N goods, each with different unit labor requirements (aLi, a*Li). • Pattern of specialization determined by relative productivity a*Li / aLi and relative

pk over time. • Explains rising service prices despite no productivity gain — the Balassa-Samuelson effect (p.48–49). VIII. EXTENSION 2: MULTIPLE TRADED GOODS • Two-country model with N goods, each with different unit labor requirements (aLi, a*Li). • Pattern of specialization determined by relative productivity a*Li / aLi and relative wage w / w*. • If a*Li / aLi > w/w*, Home produces the good. • Example (p.52): - Relative prices and comparative advantage drive production allocation. - Table shows how equilibrium prices vary based on which goods are produced where. • Equilibrium relative wage equates derived demand and fixed labor supply (p.62). • Visualization: Derived demand (RD) intersects relative labor supply (RS). IX. EXTENSION 3: TRANSPORT COSTS • With a transport cost t, goods can be produced in both countries if: (1 / (1 + t)) × (w / w*) < (a*Li / aLi) < (w / w*) × (1 + t) • High transport costs increase likelihood of non-traded goods. End of Lecture 9 Notes
(1 + t) • High transport costs increase likelihood of non-traded goods. End of Lecture 9 Notes

Lecture 11: Specific Factors Model MOTIVATION • In the short run (5–15 years), some factors (labor) are mobile across sectors, while others (capital) are not. • Labor reallocates quickly after shocks (~6 years); capital adjusts slowly (15–50 years). • We analyze trade under this temporary rigidity — capital is sector-specific, labor is flexible. MODEL SETUP • Production functions: QC = FC(KC, LC), QF = FF(KF, LF) • Capital (KC, KF) is fixed; labor (L) is mobile between sectors: L = LC + LF • Capital can be physical or land, representing sector-specific assets. PPF (Production Possibility Frontier) • Shape is determined by FC, FF and endowments (KC, KF, L). • Movement along PPF = labor reallocation between sectors. • Opportunity cost of C = MPLF / MPLC — increasing in C due to diminishing returns. • Diagram on page 11 shows bowed-out PPF. AUTARKY AND TRADE EQUILIBRIUM • Autarky: prices and allocation determined by intersection of RS and RD curves. • With trade: world price pC/pF determines production and consumption points. • Diagram on page 12–13 shows movement from autarky to trade equilibrium. FACTOR PRICES • Wages: w = pC × MPLC = pF × MPLF (equalized due to mobility)

and allocation determined by intersection of RS and RD curves. • With trade: world price pC/pF determines production and consumption points. • Diagram on page 12–13 shows movement from autarky to trade equilibrium. FACTOR PRICES • Wages: w = pC × MPLC = pF × MPLF (equalized due to mobility) • Capital returns: rC = pC × MPKC, rF = pF × MPKF (sector-specific) • Diminishing returns: reallocating labor changes MPLs and marginal product of capital. • This leads to incomplete specialization. WAGE DETERMINATION • Diagrams (p.14–16): wage is where pC × MPLC = pF × MPLF • Wage expressed in purchasing power terms (w/pF and w/pC) • Trade shifts labor to sector with comparative advantage → reallocation increases w/pF, decreases w/pC. TRADE EFFECTS ON WAGES AND ALLOCATION • Graph (p.17): country with advantage in C moves labor from F to C. • Workers’ real wage rises in F units, falls in C units — net welfare effect ambiguous. • Capital in export sector gains; capital in import sector loses. EVALUATING WELFARE • If both w/pF and w/pC increase → workers better off (independent of preferences) • If both decrease → workers worse off • Capital gains or losses determined

falls in C units — net welfare effect ambiguous. • Capital in export sector gains; capital in import sector loses. EVALUATING WELFARE • If both w/pF and w/pC increase → workers better off (independent of preferences) • If both decrease → workers worse off • Capital gains or losses determined by sector exposure. CAPITAL OWNER WELFARE • Export sector capital owners (C): rC/pC and rC/pF increase → welfare rises. • Import sector capital owners (F): rF/pF and rF/pC fall → welfare falls. • Effects hold even if labor does not reallocate (very short run). EXTENDED INSIGHTS • Worker reallocation further amplifies gains in export sector, losses in import sector. • With equal numbers of workers and capitalists: (w + rC + rF)/pC and /pF measure aggregate welfare. RELATIVE WELFARE COMPARISONS • w/rC falls → capitalists in C gain more than workers. • w/rF rises → workers gain more than capitalists in F. • Summary: Export sector capitalists gain most, import sector capitalists lose most. TERMS OF TRADE SHOCKS • Improvements in terms of trade benefit specific factors in export sector, hurt those in import sector. • Workers’ welfare rises relative to import-specific capital but falls relative to export-specific capital. •

in F. • Summary: Export sector capitalists gain most, import sector capitalists lose most. TERMS OF TRADE SHOCKS • Improvements in terms of trade benefit specific factors in export sector, hurt those in import sector. • Workers’ welfare rises relative to import-specific capital but falls relative to export-specific capital. • Reverse effects occur if terms of trade deteriorate. End of Lecture 11 Notes

Lecture 12: Specific Factors Model (II) MODEL SETUP • Production functions: QC = FC(KC, LC), QF = FF(KF, LF) • KC and KF are fixed; labor L is mobile across sectors (L = LC + LF) • Factor payments: rC = pC × MPKC, rF = pF × MPKF, w = pC × MPLC = pF × MPLF • Real wage in F terms: w/pF = MPLF = (pC/pF) × MPLC DUTCH DISEASE • Example: Dutch natural gas boom led to decline in manufacturing competitiveness. • Modern analogs: Alberta oil boom, U.S. fracking boom. • Resource booms can crowd out other sectors due to real wage pressure and exchange rate effects. EFFECTS OF CAPITAL ACCUMULATION (KC ↑) • Shifts MPLC upward, raises equilibrium wage. • Labor shifts to cloth sector: LC ↑, LF ↓ • Welfare effects: - Workers: w/pF and w/pC both ↑ → better off - Capital in F: MPKF ↓ → rF/pC ↓ → worse off - Capital in C: MPKC ↓ (since %∆KC > %∆LC) → rC/pF ↓ → worse off EFFECTS OF LABOR ACCUMULATION (L ↑) • Labor expands in both sectors: LC ↑, LF ↑ • MPLC and MPLF ↓ → real wage falls

F: MPKF ↓ → rF/pC ↓ → worse off - Capital in C: MPKC ↓ (since %∆KC > %∆LC) → rC/pF ↓ → worse off EFFECTS OF LABOR ACCUMULATION (L ↑) • Labor expands in both sectors: LC ↑, LF ↑ • MPLC and MPLF ↓ → real wage falls → workers worse off • MPKC and MPKF ↑ → capital owners better off • Historical note: U.S. labor unions supported immigration restrictions in the 1920s UNBIASED VS. BIASED GROWTH • If all factors grow proportionally → PPF expands uniformly → no relative price change • If KC grows disproportionately → RS shifts outward → growth biased toward C • If KF grows more → growth biased toward F FACTOR ABUNDANCE AND COMPARATIVE ADVANTAGE • Two countries with same technologies but different endowments: - Home: KC/L ≥ KC*/L*, KF/L ≤ KF*/L* - Home has comparative advantage in C; Foreign in F • Illustrated by RS shifts on page 60 MODEL SUMMARY • Trade doesn’t eliminate the import sector, unlike in Ricardian model • Changes in prices (pT) cause redistribution across labor and capital incomes • Even with same tech, differing factor abundance drives comparative advantage • Flexibility of factor mobility

F • Illustrated by RS shifts on page 60 MODEL SUMMARY • Trade doesn’t eliminate the import sector, unlike in Ricardian model • Changes in prices (pT) cause redistribution across labor and capital incomes • Even with same tech, differing factor abundance drives comparative advantage • Flexibility of factor mobility mitigates inequality effects of trade End of Lecture 12 Notes

Lecture 13: Heckscher-Ohlin Model (I) MODEL OVERVIEW • Long-run model: all factors (labor and capital) are mobile across sectors. • Goods (C and F) use different factor intensities: - C is labor-intensive - F is capital-intensive • Countries differ in factor endowments, not technology. • These differences create variation in PPFs and RS curves. PRODUCTION SETUP • Production functions: QC = FC(KC, LC), QF = FF(KF, LF) • Total labor and capital constraints: L = LC + LF, K = KC + KF • Labor and capital mobility → same w and r across sectors (if both goods produced). • At equilibrium: pC/MPLC = pF/MPLF and pC/MPKC = pF/MPKF • Jointly solve for efficient factor allocation and prices. PRODUCTION AND FACTOR PRICING • Given factor prices (w, r), cost-minimization determines input coefficients (aLC, aKC, aLF, aKF). • Given input coefficients, prices must satisfy: - pC = w × aLC + r × aKC - pF = w × aLF + r × aKF • Invertible system → unique mapping from prices to factor returns. • Input coefficients + endowments determine QC, QF, LC, LF, KC, KF FACTOR PRICE EQUALIZATION • If countries share tech and goods prices, then (w, r)

r × aKC - pF = w × aLF + r × aKF • Invertible system → unique mapping from prices to factor returns. • Input coefficients + endowments determine QC, QF, LC, LF, KC, KF FACTOR PRICE EQUALIZATION • If countries share tech and goods prices, then (w, r) must be equal. • Trade in goods acts as substitute for trade in factors. • This only holds under specific conditions: same technologies, both goods produced, no transport costs, etc. RELATIVE FACTOR DEMAND • Relative factor price (w/r) determines input mix LC/KC and LF/KF • Higher w/r → firms substitute K for L → RD curve shifts • Aggregate L/K determined by endowments, must match weighted average of sectoral ratios. RELATIVE PRODUCTION • Relative output (QC/QF) increases in w/r. • As more of labor-intensive good C is produced, demand for L rises → w/r rises. • Illustrated in diagram (p.12): positive relation between QC/QF and w/r RELATIVE PRICES AND OUTPUT • Relative prices (pC/pF) determine output mix. • Higher pC/pF → more C produced → w/r increases. • Graphs on pages 14–15 show stepwise relation. MARTINI EXAMPLE (NUMERICAL SIMULATION) • Goods: dry vs. regular martinis; factors: gin and vermouth •

positive relation between QC/QF and w/r RELATIVE PRICES AND OUTPUT • Relative prices (pC/pF) determine output mix. • Higher pC/pF → more C produced → w/r increases. • Graphs on pages 14–15 show stepwise relation. MARTINI EXAMPLE (NUMERICAL SIMULATION) • Goods: dry vs. regular martinis; factors: gin and vermouth • Dry uses more gin; regular uses more vermouth. • Endowments of gin and vermouth fixed. • Prices of martinis (pD, pM) determine factor values (wG, wV) • System of equations: - pM = (1/3)wV + (2/3)wG - pD = (1/6)wV + (5/6)wG - Inverted to solve for factor prices. • Production allocations: - 1/3QM + 1/6QD = V - 2/3QM + 5/6QD = G - Solve to get: QM = 5V − G, QD = 2G − 4V (if both positive) • Martini Possibility Frontier (p.59–60): linear segments, slope changes based on binding constraint (gin or vermouth) KEY TAKEAWAYS • Factor endowments determine relative prices via relative supply shifts. • Factor mobility equalizes w, r across sectors. • Factor prices are pinned down by goods prices under full specialization. • Goods trade transmits effects of endowment differences across countries. End of Lecture 13 Notes

Factor endowments determine relative prices via relative supply shifts. • Factor mobility equalizes w, r across sectors. • Factor prices are pinned down by goods prices under full specialization. • Goods trade transmits effects of endowment differences across countries. End of Lecture 13 Notes

Lecture 14: Heckscher-Ohlin Model (II) TWO-COUNTRY TRADE EQUILIBRIUM • Same technologies and preferences across countries. • Country A: capital-abundant; Country B: labor-abundant. • L*/K* > L/K → differing factor endowments imply different relative supply curves. • Shared preferences and technologies → identical relative demand (RD) curves. FACTOR ABUNDANCE AND FACTOR PRICES • Factor abundance shapes equilibrium (w/r) via shifts in RD. • A range of free trade prices allows both countries to avoid complete specialization. • Factor price equalization occurs if both goods are produced in both countries. • Diagram (p.5–7): RD curves differ due to factor endowment differences; more labor → higher relative L demand. RELATIVE GOODS SUPPLY AND COMPARATIVE ADVANTAGE • Relative goods supply curves shift based on aggregate labor allocation. • Diagram (p.9): RS* flatter in labor-abundant country → more C. • Heckscher-Ohlin Theorem: - Labor-abundant country exports labor-intensive goods (C). - Capital-abundant country exports capital-intensive goods (F). COMPLETE VS INCOMPLETE SPECIALIZATION • One country may fully specialize if: - Its comparative advantage is strong. - It is much smaller relative to its trade partner. • Both countries can fully specialize if factor abundance differences are extreme (p.19). ALTERNATIVE PROOF OF HO THEOREM • Integrated equilibrium model:

(F). COMPLETE VS INCOMPLETE SPECIALIZATION • One country may fully specialize if: - Its comparative advantage is strong. - It is much smaller relative to its trade partner. • Both countries can fully specialize if factor abundance differences are extreme (p.19). ALTERNATIVE PROOF OF HO THEOREM • Integrated equilibrium model: total world endowments = sum of both countries. • Vector diagrams (p.20–22) show factor allocation across countries. • Parallelogram model visualizes production and consumption bundles for Home and Foreign. • Vector slope = w/r ratio. TRADE AND WELFARE IN THE LONG RUN • Trade changes relative prices → long-run changes in factor rewards. • In developed countries (capital/skill abundant), trade increases return to capital and skill → raises inequality. • If factor endowment differences are too large, trade may not change factor prices (due to specialization). STOLPER-SAMUELSON THEOREM • An increase in the price of a good raises real return of the factor used intensively in that good, and lowers the return of the other factor. • Example: If pC rises and C is labor-intensive → w ↑, r ↓ • Implication: Trade can harm specific factors even if overall gains occur. • Formalized via differentiation of zero-profit condition: -

of the factor used intensively in that good, and lowers the return of the other factor. • Example: If pC rises and C is labor-intensive → w ↑, r ↓ • Implication: Trade can harm specific factors even if overall gains occur. • Formalized via differentiation of zero-profit condition: - w and r shift based on price changes and cost shares (θLi). • Diagram (p.31): clearly shows direction of welfare shifts for labor and capital. End of Lecture 14 Notes

Lecture 15: Heckscher-Ohlin Model (III) LONG-RUN EFFECTS OF FACTOR ACCUMULATION • Small open economy assumption: pT fixed. • Immigration (L ↑) shifts production towards labor-intensive goods (C). • Relative supply shifts outward: QC/QF ↑. • Capital and labor both move into C sector: - LC/L and KC/K ↑; LF/L and KF/K ↓ - QC increases more than proportionally; QF falls RYBCZYNSKI THEOREM • In a small, incompletely specialized open economy: - ↑ endowment of a factor → ↑ output of the good using it intensively - ↓ output of the other good • Dual of Stolper-Samuelson Theorem IMMIGRATION AND WAGES DEBATE • Immigration doesn't necessarily lower wages. • Partial equilibrium neglects production reallocation toward labor-intensive goods. • General equilibrium: increased demand for labor offsets supply shock. MARIEL BOATLIFT • Case study: sudden increase in low-skilled labor in Miami (1980). • Minimal effect on native wages — supports model prediction. HECKSCHER-OHLIN-VANEK (HOV) THEOREM • Factor content of trade reflects factor abundance differences. • Definitions: - Fi = ATi where Ti = (QC − DC, QF − DF) - A = matrix of input coefficients • If: 1. Technologies are identical 2. Factor price equalization holds 3. Preferences are identical and homothetic

(HOV) THEOREM • Factor content of trade reflects factor abundance differences. • Definitions: - Fi = ATi where Ti = (QC − DC, QF − DF) - A = matrix of input coefficients • If: 1. Technologies are identical 2. Factor price equalization holds 3. Preferences are identical and homothetic Then: - Fi = Vi − (Yi/YW) × VW - Vi = (Li, Ki), VW = (LW, KW) LEONTIEF PARADOX • Leontief (1953) found U.S. (capital-abundant) exported labor-intensive goods. • Baldwin (1971) refined data: paradox not generalizable. • Paradox disappeared in post-1970s data. MULTI-COUNTRY EXTENSIONS • Bowen, Leamer, Sveikauskas (1987): - HOV holds across many countries/factors. - If country’s share of factor > income share → net exporter of that factor. EMPIRICAL PREDICTIONS • U.S., Japan: exporters of capital, skilled labor • China, India: exporters of unskilled labor HOV SIGN TEST • For each country-factor pair: - If relative abundance > income share → country should be net exporter of that factor VOLUME OF TRADE PREDICTIONS • Greater factor abundance difference → more trade (holding size constant) • Empirically weak: developed countries with similar endowments do most of the trading WHY HO PERFORMS POORLY IN DATA • Unrealistic assumptions: identical

> income share → country should be net exporter of that factor VOLUME OF TRADE PREDICTIONS • Greater factor abundance difference → more trade (holding size constant) • Empirically weak: developed countries with similar endowments do most of the trading WHY HO PERFORMS POORLY IN DATA • Unrealistic assumptions: identical tech, no trade costs, factor price equalization • Doesn't explain non-traded goods, services, or firm-level heterogeneity TECHNOLOGY DIFFERENCES • Large productivity differences persist across countries and factors • Affects trade patterns beyond factor endowment explanations NORTH-SOUTH TRADE • HO model does well in explaining composition of North-South trade (e.g. skill vs. unskilled) GROWTH AND SKILL ACCUMULATION • Long-run dynamics: growth and education shifts alter comparative advantage End of Lecture 15 Notes

Lecture 16: Trade and Inequality EARLY EVIDENCE • U.S. wage inequality has risen since the 1980s, especially the college premium (p.6). • Relative wages and employment for nonproduction workers have increased (p.8). • Inequality partly reflected in divergence of real wages across percentiles (p.9). • Lower-income households face faster food price inflation (p.10). • Rent increases are linked to college share growth (p.11). TRADE AND WAGE INEQUALITY • Rising trade openness coincided with rising inequality (p.12), but causality is unclear. • Export prices didn’t rise more in skill-intensive sectors → weak Stolper-Samuelson support (p.13). • Most demand shifts for skills occur within industries, not between them (p.14). • Early conclusion: SBTC (skill-biased technological change) more important than trade (p.15). • Other factors: offshoring, Feenstra & Hanson hypothesis. CHINA SHOCK • North-South trade growth driven by China’s export surge (p.18–19). • China’s share of global manufacturing and exports rose sharply after 2001 (WTO entry). • Import penetration varied across industries (p.20), affecting local labor markets unevenly (p.21). • Demographic breakdown: most affected U.S. areas had more non-Hispanic white, low-educated, older, and poor populations (p.22). • Regional outcomes: manufacturing job loss, higher unemployment, lower wages, increased transfer receipts (p.23–24). POLITICAL IMPACTS •

2001 (WTO entry). • Import penetration varied across industries (p.20), affecting local labor markets unevenly (p.21). • Demographic breakdown: most affected U.S. areas had more non-Hispanic white, low-educated, older, and poor populations (p.22). • Regional outcomes: manufacturing job loss, higher unemployment, lower wages, increased transfer receipts (p.23–24). POLITICAL IMPACTS • Exposure to Chinese import competition shifted votes toward Trump in 2016 (p.25). • Counterfactuals: small changes in Chinese import growth could have flipped swing states (p.26). AGGREGATE EFFECTS OF TRADE • U.S. manufacturing employment declined long before China’s rise (p.27). • Offshoring and automation also key drivers. TRADE VS. TECHNOLOGICAL CHANGE REVISITED • Europe experienced similar import growth but smaller inequality increases (p.29). • U.S. firms exposed to China reduced patenting activity, especially in low-skill sectors (p.30). End of Lecture 16 Notes

Lecture 17: Increasing Returns to Scale & Monopolistic Competition INTRODUCTION • Standard trade models can't explain: - Intra-industry trade (e.g. U.S. exporting and importing motorcycles) - Trade among similar countries • Increasing returns and product differentiation fill this gap. TWO TYPES OF INCREASING RETURNS 1. Internal to firms: unit cost declines as firm output increases 2. External to firms: unit cost declines with total industry output (e.g. shared suppliers, skilled labor pool) TECHNOLOGY AND RETURNS TO SCALE • Example: fixed cost of 5 labor units, constant marginal cost of 1 • Average cost declines with output size (due to fixed cost being spread out) MONOPOLISTIC COMPETITION SETUP • Firms produce differentiated varieties and face fixed + constant marginal costs • In autarky: small countries support fewer varieties • Trade allows access to a larger market: more efficient production, greater variety MONOPOLY BEHAVIOR • A firm faces a downward-sloping demand curve • Marginal revenue is always below price due to price-reducing effect on total revenue • Profit-maximization rule: MR = MC (constant) RESIDUAL DEMAND & MARKET POWER • Residual demand depends on: - Number of firms (N) - Total market size (S) - Degree of product differentiation (b) • As N

• Marginal revenue is always below price due to price-reducing effect on total revenue • Profit-maximization rule: MR = MC (constant) RESIDUAL DEMAND & MARKET POWER • Residual demand depends on: - Number of firms (N) - Total market size (S) - Degree of product differentiation (b) • As N ↑, residual demand shrinks; as b ↓, products become closer substitutes NEW TRADE THEORY (KRUGMAN) • Larger markets → support more firms → more product variety • Endogenous variety arises from interaction between market size and fixed costs • Residual demand: Q = S[(1/N) - b(P - P̄)] MONOPOLISTIC COMPETITION EQUILIBRIUM • Firms set same price, produce Q = S/N • Price: P = c + 1/(bN) • Average cost: AC = NF/S + c • Entry continues until P = AC → zero profit equilibrium • Diagram (p.26–27): intersection of P curve and AC curve determines equilibrium N* TRADE AND GAINS FROM VARIETY • Free trade doubles market size (S↑), increases N, reduces AC • Gains from trade: - More firms and product variety (N↑) - Larger firm size, lower average cost - Lower prices for consumers • Diagram (p.27–28): shows gains from market integration SUMMARY • Trade between

AND GAINS FROM VARIETY • Free trade doubles market size (S↑), increases N, reduces AC • Gains from trade: - More firms and product variety (N↑) - Larger firm size, lower average cost - Lower prices for consumers • Diagram (p.27–28): shows gains from market integration SUMMARY • Trade between similar countries driven by scale economies and variety demand • Explains intra-industry trade and welfare gains not based on comparative advantage End of Lecture 17 Notes

Lecture 18: Consequences of Increasing Returns — Theory and Evidence INTRA- AND INTER-INDUSTRY TRADE • Inter-industry trade reflects comparative advantage (factor abundance, Ricardian tech). • Intra-industry trade arises from increasing returns and product differentiation. • Helpman & Krugman: 2-industry model with skilled/unskilled labor, IRS in cloth (monopolistic comp), CRS in food (perfect comp). • More intra-industry trade occurs: - Between large countries - In differentiated sectors - In capital/skill-intensive industries (developed countries) HOME-MARKET EFFECT • In presence of trade costs, firms prefer to locate in larger markets → higher wages and firm concentration. • Geography strongly affects GDP per capita (e.g. Paraguay, Sri Lanka, Zimbabwe would see large GDP gains by being located near Hungary). • Empirical evidence: countries with more market access (foreign and domestic) have higher GDP per capita (see scatterplots, p.17–18). FIRM HETEROGENEITY • Firms differ in productivity, input use, and export behavior. • Exporters are larger, more productive, more skill-intensive. • Most firms do not export; only the most productive do so. • Entry and exit thresholds arise from fixed and variable trade costs. • Exporting raises firm size and markup; less productive firms exit when trade liberalizes. TECHNOLOGY DIFFERENCES AND MONOPOLISTIC COMPETITION • More productive

more productive, more skill-intensive. • Most firms do not export; only the most productive do so. • Entry and exit thresholds arise from fixed and variable trade costs. • Exporting raises firm size and markup; less productive firms exit when trade liberalizes. TECHNOLOGY DIFFERENCES AND MONOPOLISTIC COMPETITION • More productive firms: larger, lower-cost, higher profit. • Trade liberalization: - Increases competition, shifts demand inward. - Low-productivity firms exit. - High-productivity firms expand and export more. • Result: aggregate productivity rises from composition effect. EVIDENCE ON TRADE LIBERALIZATION • Chile (1979–85): 2/3 of 19% productivity gain due to composition effects. • U.S.: 1% decrease in trade costs → 4% higher exit rate for non-exporters. • Canada (US-Canada FTA 1989–96): - Import-competing sectors: −12% employment, +15% productivity (half from composition) - Export sectors: no job loss, +14% productivity • NAFTA: increased U.S. import variety from Mexico (e.g., 14% in electronics, 13% in apparel). End of Lecture 18 Notes
apparel). End of Lecture 18 Notes

Lecture 19: Increasing Returns (III) — Dumping and External Economies of Scale DUMPING: DEFINITION AND RATIONALE • Dumping = export price < domestic price + per-unit trade cost. • A form of price discrimination under imperfect competition. • Requires: 1. Imperfect competition 2. Market segmentation • Firms face different demand in domestic vs. export markets (due to home bias and transportation costs). • Higher domestic market share → less price sensitivity → higher markups. • Export markets → more competition → lower markups → dumping. • Diagram (p.8) illustrates lower export price due to flatter demand and higher competition. U.S. ANTI-DUMPING LAWS • U.S. Commerce Dept. investigates injury from dumping → anti-dumping duties imposed in 93% of cases. • Duties = difference between actual and “fair” price (average duty = 57%). • International Trade Commission (ITC) assesses injury; 50% of cases result in duties remaining. • Example: 2017 softwood lumber case from Canada (p.10). • Originated ~1900; expanded post-Tokyo Round (1979); many cases filed against China. • Charts on pages 12–13 show duties by developed vs. developing countries. RECIPROCAL DUMPING MODEL (BRANDER-KRUGMAN) • Two-country duopoly; firms sell to both markets. • Intra-industry trade in identical goods with transport costs →

case from Canada (p.10). • Originated ~1900; expanded post-Tokyo Round (1979); many cases filed against China. • Charts on pages 12–13 show duties by developed vs. developing countries. RECIPROCAL DUMPING MODEL (BRANDER-KRUGMAN) • Two-country duopoly; firms sell to both markets. • Intra-industry trade in identical goods with transport costs → cross-hauling is inefficient. • Welfare ambiguous due to duplicated shipping and limited strategic interaction. EXTERNAL ECONOMIES OF SCALE • Marshallian external economies: cost ↓ as industry-wide output ↑ (not firm-specific). • Sources: 1. Specialized suppliers (e.g. Silicon Valley) 2. Labor pooling 3. Knowledge spillovers • Leads to agglomeration and industry clustering. INEFFICIENT SPECIALIZATION • Historical accidents may lock countries into suboptimal specializations. • Diagram (p.19): country 2 has lower AC but loses industry to country 1 due to path-dependence. • External IRS makes trade path-dependent — different from internal IRS. GAINS AND LOSSES FROM TRADE • Concentrating production in one country yields global gains if efficient. • But national losses possible (Graham 1928): - Country may import from a higher-cost foreign producer. DYNAMIC EXTERNAL ECONOMIES OF SCALE • Average costs fall with cumulative output (learning-by-doing). • Relevant in high-tech sectors like aerospace. • Diagram (p.23) shows downward-sloping learning curve. •

country yields global gains if efficient. • But national losses possible (Graham 1928): - Country may import from a higher-cost foreign producer. DYNAMIC EXTERNAL ECONOMIES OF SCALE • Average costs fall with cumulative output (learning-by-doing). • Relevant in high-tech sectors like aerospace. • Diagram (p.23) shows downward-sloping learning curve. • Justifies “infant industry” protection: - Key question: which industries and for how long? End of Lecture 19 Notes

Lecture 20: Trade Policy I — Tariffs TARIFF TOOLS AND TYPES • Governments restrict trade using: - Tariffs (specific or ad valorem) - Quotas and voluntary export restraints (VERs) - Regulatory barriers: testing, customs, labeling, local content rules • Tariffs raise domestic prices and reduce import volumes. PARTIAL EQUILIBRIUM FRAMEWORK • Tariff analysis often uses partial equilibrium: - Sector-specific focus, ignores macro effects - Sector is small relative to the whole economy • Standard S&D tools apply: analyze domestic supply, demand, import demand (MD), and export supply (XS). IMPACT OF TARIFFS ON PRICES • Tariff raises domestic price above world price (pW). • Reduces imports and domestic consumption. • For a large country: - Tariff lowers world price due to reduced demand → terms of trade gain. - Domestic price rises less than full tariff amount. • For a small country: - No effect on world price - Domestic price rises fully by tariff amount WELFARE ANALYSIS • Consumer surplus: area under demand curve above price • Producer surplus: area above supply curve below price • Under free trade: - Consumers benefit from low pW (large CS) - Producers receive pW, sell lower quantities • Under tariff (large importer): 1.

rises fully by tariff amount WELFARE ANALYSIS • Consumer surplus: area under demand curve above price • Producer surplus: area above supply curve below price • Under free trade: - Consumers benefit from low pW (large CS) - Producers receive pW, sell lower quantities • Under tariff (large importer): 1. Consumer surplus ↓ (area 1+2+3+4) 2. Producer surplus ↑ (area 1) 3. Tariff revenue = 3+5 4. Net welfare = 5 − 2 − 4 (could be gain or loss) • Area 2: production distortion — producing units above world MC • Area 4: consumption distortion — consumers priced out despite value > pW • For small countries, area 5 disappears → tariffs always reduce welfare OPTIMAL TARIFF CONCEPT • For a large country, a small tariff may increase welfare via improved terms of trade. • There exists an “optimal” tariff level t*. • Optimal tariff increases with inelasticity of foreign export supply. TRUMP TARIFFS AND EMPIRICAL EVIDENCE • Timeline (page 5) shows major 2018 tariff actions on washers, solar panels, steel, aluminum, and China-specific goods. • Event study (page 51): - Tariffs raised log unit value of imports (including duties) - Variety and quantity fell slightly - Suggests importers

foreign export supply. TRUMP TARIFFS AND EMPIRICAL EVIDENCE • Timeline (page 5) shows major 2018 tariff actions on washers, solar panels, steel, aluminum, and China-specific goods. • Event study (page 51): - Tariffs raised log unit value of imports (including duties) - Variety and quantity fell slightly - Suggests importers bore much of the cost. End of Lecture 20 Notes

Lecture 21: Trade Policy II — Other Instruments OPTIMAL TARIFFS & POLITICAL ECONOMY • Optimal tariff balances social marginal benefit (SMB) of imports with marginal cost (SMC). - SMB = value of extra consumption or less production (at domestic price p). - SMC = world price + effect on infra-marginal imports. - Optimal tariff condition: (p - pW)/pW = 1/η (inverse export supply elasticity)【220†source】. • Broda, Limao & Weinstein (2008): Higher inverse supply elasticity correlates with higher tariffs (graph on p.13)【220†source】. • Politicians may set tariffs above optimal level due to increasing revenue and producer surplus. • Even optimal tariffs cause global inefficiencies → leads to institutions like GATT/WTO to reduce them. QUOTAS & VOLUNTARY EXPORT RESTRAINTS (VERs) • Quotas restrict import quantity, raise domestic prices (like tariffs). • Under perfect competition, tariffs and quotas are equivalent in effects on price, surplus, and imports【220†source】. • Difference: Quotas generate rents that may go to: 1. Domestic firms (via license auction) 2. Exporter governments (VERs, e.g., U.S. auto quotas from Japan) • With market power, quotas worsen welfare relative to tariffs due to higher prices and distorted incentives (graph p.29)【220†source】. CASE STUDY: U.S. SUGAR QUOTA • USDA guarantees breakeven price for domestic

may go to: 1. Domestic firms (via license auction) 2. Exporter governments (VERs, e.g., U.S. auto quotas from Japan) • With market power, quotas worsen welfare relative to tariffs due to higher prices and distorted incentives (graph p.29)【220†source】. CASE STUDY: U.S. SUGAR QUOTA • USDA guarantees breakeven price for domestic producers → high demand → 1.4M ton import quota imposed【220†source】. • Foreign governments administer quota → retain rents. • U.S. sugar price ≈ 2× world price (see p.38 chart)【220†source】. • Welfare in 2002: - Consumer loss: $2.47B, Producer gain: $1.8B - Rents: $364M, Net loss: $662M【220†source】. - $200k–$500k per job saved (12–38k workers, p.44) • Political economy: Sugar concentrated in Florida, heavy lobbying, campaign donations (e.g., Fanjul brothers). EXPORT SUBSIDIES • Raises domestic price above pW: p = pW + s • Re-imports often banned (or offset by tariffs). • In small open economy: 1. ↓ Consumer surplus (a+b) 2. ↑ Producer surplus (a+b+c) 3. Government cost = (b+c+d) 4. Net loss = b+d (distortions)【220†source】. • Common in agriculture; discouraged by WTO. End of Lecture 21 Notes
↑ Producer surplus (a+b+c) 3. Government cost = (b+c+d) 4. Net loss = b+d (distortions)【220†source】. • Common in agriculture; discouraged by WTO. End of Lecture 21 Notes

Lecture 22: Trade Policy (III) TRADE POLICY AS A SECOND-BEST INSTRUMENT • Under perfect competition, tariffs cannot improve welfare in small open economies. • With market failures (e.g. production externalities), tariffs can serve as second-best tools. • Example: positive production externality → private benefit < social benefit. • A production subsidy is preferred to a tariff, as it avoids consumption distortion【229†source】. • See diagrams on pages 6–7: subsidy shifts supply without raising price as tariffs do. STRATEGIC TRADE POLICY • Under imperfect competition, firms earn profits — governments may intervene to shift profits to domestic firms. • Brander & Spencer model: export subsidies can alter firm behavior in duopolies. • Game setup: - Two firms (Boeing, Airbus); two governments (U.S., EU); third market (China). - Without subsidy: multiple Nash equilibria. - With EU subsidy: shifts equilibrium to favor Airbus【229†source】. • Caveats: - Requires precise information. - Can backfire: see altered payoff matrix on pages 12–13. THE WTO • 1930s Smoot-Hawley Tariff Act → retaliatory tariffs → global recession. • 1947: GATT created — multilateral tariff reduction over eight trade rounds. • 1995: WTO established with expanded scope (services, IP, dispute settlement)【229†source】. TERMS-OF-TRADE AND PRISONER’S DILEMMA • A large country can

payoff matrix on pages 12–13. THE WTO • 1930s Smoot-Hawley Tariff Act → retaliatory tariffs → global recession. • 1947: GATT created — multilateral tariff reduction over eight trade rounds. • 1995: WTO established with expanded scope (services, IP, dispute settlement)【229†source】. TERMS-OF-TRADE AND PRISONER’S DILEMMA • A large country can benefit from tariffs (area 5 − (2+4)), but at the partner’s expense (area 5+6+7)【229†source】. • If both countries impose tariffs: Nash equilibrium leads to mutual losses. • WTO’s role: enforce cooperation to escape the prisoner’s dilemma (pages 18–20). ENVIRONMENTAL CASES • WTO often challenged over environmental rules. • *Gasoline Case* (1995): U.S. EPA standards ruled discriminatory against imports (Venezuela, Brazil)【229†source】. • *Tuna-Dolphin Case* (1991): U.S. dolphin-safe fishing ban overturned for violating GATT extraterritoriality. • *GM Food Case* (2003–2006): EU ban on GM foods ruled invalid due to lack of scientific evidence【229†source】. TRUMP TRADE WAR REVISITED • Tariff escalation from 2018 shown in charts (p.21–22): - Panel A: U.S. tariffs on washers, solar, steel, and China. - Panel B: Retaliatory tariffs from China, EU, Canada, and others. End of Lecture 22 Notes
shown in charts (p.21–22): - Panel A: U.S. tariffs on washers, solar, steel, and China. - Panel B: Retaliatory tariffs from China, EU, Canada, and others. End of Lecture 22 Notes

Lecture 23: Factor Mobility (I) — Labor Migration ONE-GOOD MODEL OF MIGRATION • Two countries (Home and Foreign), one good (Output), no trade. • Output: Q = F(K, L); price normalized to 1. • Capital fixed, labor mobile across countries. • Properties: Constant returns to scale, diminishing marginal returns, and factor complementarity. • Competitive factor markets: w = MPL, r = MPK; Q = wL + rK. MIGRATION MOTIVATION & OUTCOMES • Workers migrate where utility is higher → higher wages. • Wages are higher in capital-abundant countries due to complementarity. • Migration continues until wage equalization. • Graphs (pages 9–11): show wage convergence and gains from migration (green area = surplus). ECONOMIC BENEFITS OF MIGRATION • Home benefits because wage paid < MPL of migrants. • Abroad benefits because migrants’ wage > MPL*. • Surplus = ½(w − w′)(L2 − L1) → ΔQ/Q = −½sem² - Borjas (1995): s = 0.7, e = −0.3, m = 0.1 → ΔQ/Q = 0.1% • Kremer & Watt (2006) estimate gains closer to 1% of GDP. REDISTRIBUTIVE EFFECTS • Workers in labor-scarce countries lose; capitalists gain. • Opposite for labor-abundant country. • Net effects (Borjas parameters): - ΔwL/Q = sem(1 − m)

= 0.7, e = −0.3, m = 0.1 → ΔQ/Q = 0.1% • Kremer & Watt (2006) estimate gains closer to 1% of GDP. REDISTRIBUTIVE EFFECTS • Workers in labor-scarce countries lose; capitalists gain. • Opposite for labor-abundant country. • Net effects (Borjas parameters): - ΔwL/Q = sem(1 − m) ≈ 1.9% - ΔrK/Q = −sem(1 − ½m) ≈ 2.0% - Transfer from labor to capital: $133B in a $7T economy. TWO-GOOD MODEL: IMMIGRATION IN H-O SETUP • Goods: Clothing (capital-intensive), Food (labor-intensive). • Immigration mimics biased growth toward Food in a closed economy: 1. RS shifts → PF/PC falls 2. Stolper-Samuelson effect → w/r falls 3. Real wages fall, capital gains • In a small open economy: - PF/PC fixed → w/r fixed - Rybczynski effect: immigration affects output mix, not factor prices - Impact depends on trade openness EMPIRICAL EVIDENCE 1. Wage Convergence (1870–1913): - Higher wages in destination countries - Wages grew faster in origin countries - Chart on page 19 supports convergence via migration. 2. U.S. Immigration Trends: - Chart (p.21): foreign-born share dropped mid-century, rose post-1980. - Chart (p.22): shift from NW Europe to Latin America/Asia. - Skill distribution: U-shaped across education (Peri 2006, p.24).

destination countries - Wages grew faster in origin countries - Chart on page 19 supports convergence via migration. 2. U.S. Immigration Trends: - Chart (p.21): foreign-born share dropped mid-century, rose post-1980. - Chart (p.22): shift from NW Europe to Latin America/Asia. - Skill distribution: U-shaped across education (Peri 2006, p.24). 3. U.S. Wage Impact: - Borjas et al. (1996): cross-regional estimates unstable; better to use changes over time. - Final estimates often negative but modest; issues of endogeneity remain. - Card (1990): Mariel Boatlift (1980) natural experiment — no major effect on Miami wages. End of Lecture 23 Notes

Lecture 24: Offshoring — Globalization and the Fragmentation of Production OVERVIEW • Global supply chains now span multiple countries and firms. • Offshoring = relocating tasks abroad, either within firms (vertical FDI) or through outsourcing【247†source】. • Driven by advances in communication and information technology. EXAMPLES • Boeing 787 components: built in U.S., Japan, Italy, France, Korea, etc. (diagram on p.6)【247†source】. • Apple iPhone: designed in California, components from Korea, Japan, Germany, etc., assembled in Shenzhen, China (p.7)【247†source】. THE ECONOMICS OF TASK TRADE • Offshoring increases when tasks are tradable and wages are lower abroad. • Autor, Levy, and Murnane: routine vs. non-routine tasks matter (p.12)【247†source】. • Blinder: distinction between physically vs. electronically deliverable tasks. • Rising offshoring even in high-skill areas like programming and accounting. GROSSMAN & ROSSI-HANSBERG MODEL • Two types of tasks: L (low-skill) and H (high-skill). • Offshoring reduces the cost of L tasks if performed abroad. • Marginal task i offshored if a_L W = bt(i)a_L W* (p.23)【247†source】. • The cost of a unit of apparel includes offshore and onshore components (p.24–25). TECHNICAL INSIGHT • Cost savings from offshoring mimic productivity gains (p.26–27). • Lower b → more tasks offshored (I↑) → wage effects through changes

• Marginal task i offshored if a_L W = bt(i)a_L W* (p.23)【247†source】. • The cost of a unit of apparel includes offshore and onshore components (p.24–25). TECHNICAL INSIGHT • Cost savings from offshoring mimic productivity gains (p.26–27). • Lower b → more tasks offshored (I↑) → wage effects through changes in Ω(I), a cost aggregator. WAGE EFFECTS • In small open economy: - Offshoring raises domestic wages of low-skill labor (w↑) because cost savings increase demand (p.29)【247†source】. • In large open economy: - Relative-price and labor-supply effects may offset productivity gains: - Expansion of offshoring → fall in apparel prices → Stolper-Samuelson pressures on wages (p.32)【247†source】. EVIDENCE & IMPLICATIONS • Increase in imported intermediate inputs and services (charts pp.9–10)【247†source】. • Growing share of non-routine work among U.S. and German workers (pp.12–13). • Offshoring allows reallocation of labor to higher-value non-routine tasks. FINAL THOUGHTS • Offshoring ≠ threat, but a form of technological change. • Winners: high-skill, non-routine task workers. • Losers: routine task workers displaced by competition abroad. End of Lecture 24 Notes
of technological change. • Winners: high-skill, non-routine task workers. • Losers: routine task workers displaced by competition abroad. End of Lecture 24 Notes
